content.title: Essential Lighting Requirements for Mourning Geckos
content.content: Mourning geckos are crepuscular (active at sunrise and sunset), meaning they are exposed to indirect UVB in nature during these twilight periods. While they can survive without UVB due to dietary vitamin D3 from crested gecko diet, they thrive when provided with low-level UVB - especially important for egg-laying females who have elevated calcium demands. Proper lighting also regulates circadian rhythms and supports natural behaviors.

Mourning geckos fall into Ferguson Zone 1-2 (low to moderate UVB exposure). Their crepuscular activity means they receive brief, indirect UVB during dawn/dusk rather than intense midday sun exposure like diurnal species.

content.text: UVB Requirements:

rows: Allows self-regulation - geckos can choose exposure

content.content: While UVB is not strictly required if using fortified crested gecko diet, it is STRONGLY RECOMMENDED for breeding colonies. Egg-laying females need extra vitamin D3 for calcium absorption, and UVB provides this more naturally than D3 supplementation.
For tiny 12°12°18 enclosures, compact coil UVB bulbs mounted on their side provide appropriate low-level UVB. Linear tubes are ideal for larger enclosures (18°18°24+).

content.text: Recommended UVB Bulbs:

content.content: AVOID desert-strength UVB (10.0+) - this is far too intense for forest-dwelling mourning geckos and can cause eye damage and stress. Always use 5.0-7% "tropical" or "forest" rated bulbs.
UVB bulb placement affects the UV Index at basking areas. Mourning geckos need low UVI (1.0-2.0), so distance and mounting matter.

content.text: Mounting Distance Guidelines (12°12°18 Enclosure):

rows: On top of screen, hood with side mount
On top of screen or inside

content.content: Compact Coil Mounting for 12°12°18: Use a 12-inch terrarium hood with incandescent socket. Mount the 26w compact UVB bulb on its SIDE (not base-up) in the hood. Place hood on screen top so bulb is positioned horizontally across one side. Basking perch should be 2-4 inches below the screen.

Verification recommendation: Use a Solarmeter 6.5 to measure UVI at highest perch. Adjust perch height to achieve 1.0-2.0 UVI. Without a Solarmeter, follow manufacturer distance guidelines for "tropical species."
Beyond UVB, visible light is important for circadian rhythm regulation and natural behavior. Mourning geckos are crepuscular, so they need a clear day/night cycle but not intense bright light.

content.text: Visible Light Sources:

rows: Natural window light acceptable (not direct sun)

content.content: Mourning geckos do not need intense bright light like diurnal lizards. The combination of a 25w heat bulb + UVB bulb provides adequate illumination. Additional lighting is only necessary if growing demanding live plants.
Consistent light/dark cycles regulate breeding behavior, activity patterns, and overall health. Mourning geckos should have a 12/12 photoperiod (12 hours light, 12 hours dark) year-round.

content.text: Recommended Light Schedule:

content.content: Timer Setup: Use a plug-in timer (digital or mechanical) to automate light schedule. Plug both heat lamp AND UVB fixture into the timer so they turn on/off together. This ensures consistency even when you're away.

Mourning geckos are most active during the first hour after lights turn on (morning) and the first hour after lights turn off (evening). This is when you'll see breeding behaviors, hunting, and social interactions.
Mourning geckos do NOT need nighttime lighting. Red/blue/moonlight bulbs are unnecessary and can disrupt sleep.

content.text: Nighttime Lighting Do's and Don'ts:

rows: Natural sleep environment, allows nighttime temp drop
Low light from hallway/windows is fine
Visible to geckos, disrupts circadian rhythm
Provides heat without light for cold rooms

content.content: Colored nighttime bulbs (red/blue) are often marketed for nocturnal/crepuscular species, but research shows these disrupt sleep and natural behaviors. Mourning geckos can see these wavelengths. Use complete darkness or ceramic heat emitters only.
UVB output degrades over time even if the bulb still produces visible light. Replace bulbs according to manufacturer recommendations to maintain effective UVB provision.

content.text: Replacement Schedule:

rows: Write installation date on fixture with marker
Set calendar reminder for annual replacement
Longer lifespan but still track replacement

content.content: Replacement Tips: Purchase replacement bulbs in advance so you're not caught without UVB. When replacing, dispose of old bulbs properly (check local recycling guidelines for CFL bulbs). Note that visible light output does NOT indicate UVB output - bulbs can appear bright but produce minimal UVB after expiration.
While mourning geckos can survive without UVB thanks to fortified CGD, signs of deficiency may appear over time, especially in breeding females.

content.text: UVB Deficiency Indicators:

rows: Ensure UVB is functioning, vet visit required
Mother had inadequate UVB/calcium during egg development
Check UVB bulb age, ensure proper diet
Veterinary intervention needed, improve UVB immediately

content.content: Breeding colonies without UVB have higher rates of egg binding, soft eggs, and developmental issues in offspring. Do not rely solely on dietary D3 for long-term breeding success.

content.content: Pro tip: For larger enclosures (24"+), consider using a linear T5 HO UVB tube for better coverage. Compact coils work for small enclosures but linear tubes provide more even UVB distribution across wider spaces.

content.text: Common Problems & Solutions:

rows: Bulb burned out or poor socket contact
Check socket connection, replace bulb if old
Insufficient wattage or bulbs burned out
Add LED grow light or ensure heat lamp is on
Too bright or stressed (not lighting issue)
Ensure adequate foliage cover, check temps
Add dedicated LED grow light or switch to low-light plants
Heat lamp + UVB generating excessive heat
Lower heat lamp wattage or increase distance

content.content: Remember: Lighting setup should be tested and adjusted BEFORE adding geckos. Run equipment for 24-48 hours to ensure proper temperatures and light levels are achieved.
